Many factors had effects on the properties of nano-modified asphalt binder. Nano materials improved low and high temperature performances of asphalt binder. Studies on nano modified mixtures were less than those on nano modified binders. Economic, ecological and environmental evaluations of need to be considered.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 12 January 2017 Received in revised form 3 March 2017 Accepted 17 March 2017
Keywords: Nano materials Asphalt binder and mixture Nano technologies Modification Rheology
a b s t r a c t
Due to its nature of large surface area and small size, nano-material shows specific characteristics compared to the common material and exhibits some novel properties and incredible features which make it possible to be applied in the field of asphalt pavement as an additive. This review focuses on introducing the main nano materials and related techniques used for nano-modified asphalts and major performance characteristics at various states. Some conventional test results including viscosity, dynamic modulus, stiffness, rut depth, indirect tensile strength and so on were employed to characterize the rheological and engineering performances of nano-modified asphalts and some innovative technologies such as atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy were effectively utilized to explore their micro structures and molecular components. It can be found that the addition of nanomaterials could dramatically enhance the properties of an asphalt material such as visco-elasticity, high temperature properties, and the resistances to aging, fatigue and moisture. In addition, nano-particle type, content and production process were mainly studied and other factors such as binder type and particle size also need to be considered to explore the modification mechanism and effect. The properties of both nano-material and original binder played the key roles in determining optimal production process parameters. In addition, the degree of dispersion was governed by some factors such as the mixing temperature, duration and speed.

1. Introduction
Recent years, highway pavement construction industry is rapidly progressing all over the world due to a dramatic increase in traffic loads. Traditional pavement materials are hard to meet the practical demands for present and future highway pavement construction. Thus, higher quality, more safety, more reliable and more environment friendly pavement materials are urgently demanded.
As a result, various kinds of modifiers such as crumb rubber, fibers [1–8] are introduced to improve performances of asphalt materials. Styrene-butadiene-rubber (SBR) is also chose to tail the pristine asphalt [9,10]. In addition, Yildirim and his coworkers introduced ethylene glycidyl acrylate (EGA) terpolymer to enhance the performance of original binder [11]. It is true that traditional modifiers can improve performances of the asphalt and mixture. These performances include moisture susceptibility, permanent deformation, fatigue life, anti-aging and so on. However, more and more researchers concentrate on the introduction of nanomaterials to modify the asphalt due to the rapid development of nanotechnology.
Nanomaterial is described as a material with at least one dimension within 1–100 nm. Based on previous research, the properties of nano-composites such as physics, chemistry and biology of were significantly different from their initial ones [12]. Some
unique phenomena such as the tunnel effect of macroscopic quantum and surface effect were also been found attributing to the natures of its large surface area and small size. It is noted that
nanomaterials exhibited high temperature sensitivity, high ductility, large surface area, high strain resistance, and low electrical resistivity [13–17]. Because of those unique features, the application of nanomaterials is very extensive. Carbon nanotubes, nanowires, nanofibers and nanoceramics are the more commonly used nanomaterials [18]. Table 1 gives a simple summarization of application of nanomaterials.
Moreover, nano-scale materials show smart performances such as self-cleaning, self-healing, self-remembering and self-sensing capabilities. These novel phenomena and properties of nanomaterials exactly meet the demands for present highway pavement. Thus researchers and engineers incorporated the nanotechnology into the fields of pavement materials, using nano-particles to modify asphalt. Since Xiao and his coworkers [19–21] firstly added nano-particles into asphalts to study their rheological performances, various kinds of nano-particles had been used to improve the performance properties of asphalt materials during last decade. It has been proved that the addition of nanomaterials can remarkably enhance the performance properties of asphalt material such as visco-elasticity, high temperature property, and the resistances to aging, fatigue and moisture damage [20,22–25]. So nano-scale modifiers are playing more and more important roles in the study of asphalt modification [24,26–28].
This review documented the types of nano-products to tailor asphalt, summarized the preparation and mixing methods of nano-modified asphalts, and concluded the nano-techniques and test methodologies to characterize the performance properties of modified asphalt binders and mixtures. Also it further highlighted on some main challenges and considerations in order to promote large-scale application in practical engineering.
2. Materials used in Nano-modified asphalt
The following Table 2 summarizes the main nanomaterials and the original asphalts used to produce nano-modified asphalts and their recommended contents.
2.1. Nano particles
The basic unit size of nanomaterial is between 1 and 100 nm. Due to its small size, large surface area and unique physical and
chemical properties, nano-scale particles such as nano-carbon, nano-clay, nano-fiber and nano-scale spherical particles (nanoZnO, nano-SiO2, and nano-TiO2) have attracted many researchers’ interests to tailor pristine asphalt.
2.1.1. Nano-carbon Carbon nanoparticle is a black and powdery material with a huge surface area per gram. Xiao and his coworkers utilized this material to modify base asphalt [12–14]. It was found that this black particle could remarkably improve the rheological properties of asphalt and the increase of nanoparticle content resulted in high viscous and elastic modulus values, regardless of binder type.
2.1.2. Nano-clay Layered silicate (Nano-clay) is described as the clay that has a layer thickness between 1 and 100 nm and widely used in the modification of matrices to improve mechanical and thermal properties. It could be acquired mainly by the following three methods: situ polymerization [38–40], solution blending [15,41] and melt processing [24,42,43]. Meanwhile, it is the most widely used nano-particles to modify materials due to their low cost of production and abundance in nature. For instance, Abdelrahman et al. [22] employed surface-modified montmorillonite as an asphalt modification to tailor the neat asphalt. The results showed that surface-modified montmorillonite could dramatically improve the rheological properties of pristine asphalt. In addition, Liu et al. [44] utilized two different types of nano-clays Montmorillonite 1 and Montmorillonite 2 to modify the asphalt. Based on FTIR tests and SEM images, it was found that both mechanical and rheological properties of modified asphalt were good.
In general, there are two main categories of nano-clays used to tailor asphalt binder. One is nonmodified nano-clay (NMN) asphalt; another is polymer modified nano-clay (PMN) asphalt. NMN is the most frequently used layered silicates with a 2-to-1 layered structure clay consisting of one octahedral alumina sheet sandwiched between two tetrahedral silica, which was proposed by Ray and Okamoto [45]. It has been proved that the only a very small weight percent of nanoclay could dramatically enhance the compressive and shear strength of thermoplastic materials.
PMN is produced from the ion exchange of between the organic substance and the hydrophilic nano-clay. It is believed that the permeability of this material was reduced while showed an improvement of the tear and compression strength [17].
2.1.3. Nano-fiber Carbon Nano-fiber (CNF) is known to have large surface area, good interfacial bonding, high tensile modulus and high aspect ratio. The main properties of CNF are summarized in Table 3 [33]. It is believed that the high aspect ratio of fiber can produce a good network of nanocomposite. And the bridge link effect of nanofibers can effectively prevent micro-cracks from developing under the interaction of heavy vehicle loading and environmental influence. As a result, the mechanical and rheological properties of asphalt binder can be improved by incorporating with CNF.
Generally, there are main three ways to obtain carbon fiber. Melt-spinning method is the most common way. Many researchers used melt-spinning method to produce carbon fibers due to its convenience. Second method is Vapor-grown carbon fiber (VGCF),
which is a kind of fiber that produced via catalytic chemical vapor deposition. It is believed that the properties and structures of VGCF were far different from those of fibers obtained by melt-spinning method [46]. In addition, electro spinning method has also been used to produce nanofibers due to a relatively simple production process and its low cost.
2.1.4. Nano-TiO2 Titanium dioxide is the naturally occurred oxide of titanium. In nature, it is usually found in form of rutile, anatase, and brookite. Nano-scale titanium dioxide consists of 80% anatase and 20% rutile. It has been proved that nano-TiO2 has very large surface area, very small diameter, and very low opacity compared to ordinary TiO2. Themain physical properties of Nano titanium are shown in Table 4 [47]. Because of those unique properties, some researchers also utilized nano-TiO2 to improve the performance of modified asphalt [48].
Briefly, TiO2 nano-particles are prepared in the reaction system by oxidation of titanium precursor at a high temperature [49]. In general, there are two main production methods to obtain nanoTiO2. One is the sulfate process and the other is chloride process. However, both process methods have potential to cause negative impacts on environment. For instance, the former method is considered to produce a large number of acidic wastes and the chloride process method may result in a lot of solid, liquid and minerals wastes.
2.1.5. Nano-SiO2 Nanosilica is an inorganic material that was produced mainly from silica precursors. It has been widely applied to the fields such as medicine, drug delivery, and agriculture. In the field of pavement engineering, nanosilica is employed as an additive to modify asphalt. Attributing to the unique huge surface area, good dispersion ability, as well as its high and excellent stability, the performances of original asphalt are dramatically enhanced by the introduction of nano- SiO2 [30,32,47]. The main properties of Nano silica are shown in Table 5 [47].
Vapor phase method, sol-gel method and other methods are employed to produce nanosilica [50]. Among them, the sol-gel process method is considered as the most widely applied method for its mild conditions and pure products.
2.2. Asphalt
Most of researchers used only one type of asphalt in their study: Liu et al. and Yu et al. utilized #70 asphalt as pristine asphalt to analyze the property changes of nano-modified asphalt [51,52]. In addition, You et al. [53] used PG 64-28 as an original binder, Yao et al. [30] selected PG 58-34 as the control asphalt binder. Both Goh, S.W and Abdelrahman utilized PG 58-28 binder in their study [22,31]. The conventional physical properties of original asphalts are briefly concluded in Table 6.
Xiao et al. employed five different sources of asphalt binders (A: PG 64-22; B: PG 64-22; C: PG 64-22; D: PG 64-16; E: PG 52-28) [12]. In their study, statistical analysis indicated that binder type and grade played important roles on affecting the deflection, stiffness and m-values of nano-composites. In addition, softer binder (PG 52-28) was believed to have the lowest failure temperatures [19–21].
2.3. Other materials
Other materials such as acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS), silane coupling agent emulsions and so on were employed to comodify original asphalt with Nano materials in order to achieve better performances of modified asphalts. It is believed that adding ABS into polymer matrix could significantly improve the performances of nano-modified asphalt. Yao et al. utilized ABS to enhance lower temperature grade of the nano-silicon modified asphalt [30]. It is noted that the compatibility between polymer and the control PG 58-34 asphalt was dramatically improved after the addition of ABS.
Many researchers also employed silane coupling agent to obtain surface- modified nanomaterials. The most common used silane coupling agents is KH-570. For instance, Liu and his coworkers employed KH-570 in their study to get surface-modified nanoTiO2 [48]. In addition, You et al. used silane as montmorillonite (MMT) surface modification to disperse the nano-clays and observed a enhanced bonding of nano-clays with asphalt system [53]. Elsewhere, Shirakawa and his collaborators utilized emulsions to disperse CNTs into asphalt [57]. Table 7 made a simple summary of additional co-modifiers.

The high viscosity of the asphalt and the good solubility of nanoparticles may attribute for that. In addition, some researchers believed that Ostwald ripening phenomenon and van der Waals attraction force were the prime reasons forming the agglomerations [30]. As a result, the effect of agglomeration caused by inadequately dispersion would in turn deteriorate the mechanical and rheological characteristics of the modified asphalt. In addition, it was proposed that an improper mixing procedure would destroy the nano-particles and the properties of materials would significantly degenerate [35]. Thus adopting a suitable mixing method to guarantee the nano materials can be diffused homogenously is very crucial.
3.1. Mixing method
Generally, there are currently two main mixing methods used to disperse the nano-particles in the asphalt. One is the dry blending method, and another one is the solvent blending method. The advantages and disadvantages of these two methods are concluded in Table 8. It has proved that solvent blending method can achieve better dispersion of nano materials into the asphalt. However, this technique would cost more energy consumption and waste, which was not economic and environmental friendly. For example, Faramarz and his coworkers [35] used a total of 120 ml kerosene to dissolve only 1.28 gram of CNT which disobeyed the demands for economy and energy saving.
3.1.1. Dry blending method The most widely used and mature technology to produce nanomodified composite is the dry blending method due to its efficiency and simplicity. This technique is consisted of two steps. The first step is to add the nano-particles into asphalt. The second step is to mix the asphalt binder with nano particles into an adequate homogeneity. For instance, Golestani and his coworkers heated the asphalt up to 180 ± 5 C, mixed the composites under a fixed speed of 4000 rpm for 45 min and finally got the sufficiently homogenous blends [59]. In addition, Faramarzi et al. employed a hot plate to heat the asphalt under a temperature of 160 C and used an oil bath to maintain the certain temperature when dispersed the nano-composites with asphalt [35].
As for the mixing tools, Shirakawa and his coworkers chose magnetic stirrer to mix the carbon tubes with asphalt binder [57]. In contract, Yu et al. utilized a high shear mixer to achieve the goal of homogenously blended composites [51].
3.1.2. Solvent blending method The solvent melting process technique is termed ‘‘mother liquor melting”. In this method, the solvent with nano-particle was mixed with asphalt binder used a low shear mixer under the condition of a medium to high temperature until the solvent evaporated sufficiently. It has been proved that the solvent can act as a medium
bridging between the nano-particle and asphalt binder. As a result, nano-particle can achieve homogeneous distribution into the asphalt [60].
Meanwhile, it is believed that selecting a proper organic ‘‘mother liquor” plays an important role to guarantee the success of the solvent blending method. The following considerations are regarded as the key factors when choosing an appropriate solvent [33].
Good ability to dissolve in the asphalt at a room temperature without significantly influencing the physical and mechanical properties of asphalt binder. Low viscosity and high evaporation rates to ensure nanomaterials richly disperse into asphalt binder at medium to high temperatures.
Various solvents such as kerosene, varsol, turpentine and acetone would be alternative to reduce the viscosity of an asphalt and implement nanomaterials adequately dissolution into the asphalt at a room temperature. Due to cheap and easily available, researchers selected kerosene as the solvent mostly.
In order to acquire the uniform nanomaterials-solvent mixtures, both Khattak and Faramarzi [33,35] combined the techniques of sonication and high shear mixing to guarantee homogenous distribution of nanofibers into the asphalt. They selected the sonication duration of 25 min, along with 2 min of high shear mixing at 2500 rpm and sonication duration of 8 min along with 2 min of high shear mixing at 3000 rpm, respectively. Especially, Khattak and his coworkers adopted a cool-down duration of 25 min between each cycle. It was believed that incorporating those two techniques would provide enough energy to prevent aggregation of the nano-particles from destroying the structure and size. And the nanomaterials-solvent mixtures were mixed with base asphalt at a suitable temperature until the solvent was vaporized completely.
3.2. Mixing conditions
With respect to the mixing condition selection, it would become much more complex. According to Brownian motion, it is necessary to raise the temperature to allow nano-particles to diffusion more easily. In general, a high temperature can reduce the viscosity of asphalt. However, asphalt is a temperature sensitive material so that a higher temperature would accelerate aging rate which in turn would deteriorate the durability of asphalt binder. It is considered that the temperature during the preparation should not be too high. Therefore, how to balance the temperature of producing uniformly dispersed nano-modified composites and reducing the aging degree of virgin asphalt as much as possible is a big barrier which needs to be broken.
In terms of mixing time, a respectively long duration is needed to guarantee the composites are diffused uniformly. On the contrary, a longer mixing time may cause a higher energy consumption and waste, and may also increase the production cost of nano-composites. So it is also necessary to apply a well selected mixing duration. Meanwhile, a proper mixing speed is needed to make sure the sufficient dispersion of nano particles. However, an exceeded high speed may destroy the structure of nanomaterial. The following Table 9 summarizes the temperature, duration and speed which researchers utilized to produce nanomodified asphalts.
Table 9 shows temperature, duration and speed utilized by different researchers to make sure the nanomaterials uniform diffusion. Overall, the mixing conditions used to produce different types of nano-modified asphalts significantly vary. It can be concluded that the temperatures chose by researchers varied from

There are three solid-state lasers (two blue and one red) and two detector arrays in the LDA system. The LDA system can measure light scattered throughout the whole angular spectrum. Also, the multi-laser system provided direct and continuous measurements without curve fitting or blending of two different measurement technologies or wavelengths. So it is considered to have potential to provide effective information about the size distribution and
breaking down. Moreover, other valid methodologies for evaluating whether nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed need a further exploration.
4. Techniques used for Nano-modified asphalt
4.1. Traditional test
The SuperpaveTM tests are conducted to evaluate the rheological properties of nano modified binders, such as rotational viscosity (RV), dynamic shear rheometer (DSR), and bending beam rheometer (BBR). The typical methods are shown in Table 10.
4.1.1. Rotational viscosity (RV) A Brookfield rotational viscometer can be used to determine the viscosity of the binder at 135 C and 165 C. About 10.5 ml of heated asphalt binder is poured into the cylinder. The spindle is lowered into the binder and the assembly is allowed to reach an
equilibrium test temperature. The test is run at 20 rmp and the viscosity readings in Pa. s are recorded. Two samples are tested and if the difference between the two exceeds 2% the third test is conducted.
4.1.2. Dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) The DSR test can be used to measure both viscous and elastic behaviors of asphalt binder at intermediate to high temperatures based on the complex shear modulus and phase angle. Unaged and RTFO-aged binders are tested with a 25-mm-diamater plate and a 1000 mm gap. At the same time, PAV-aged binder is tested with an 8-mm- diameter plate and a 2000 mm gap. It represents the asphalt binder’s resistance to permanent deformation and fatigue cracking.
4.1.3. Bending beam rheometer (BBR) The BBR test can be used to determine the creep stiffness of asphalt binders versus loading time. The test results show the relationship between the low temperature and asphalt binders, and indicating the stress relaxation when constant loading (0.98 N) is applied in the asphalt beam.
Besides, some developments of the tradition tests to evaluate the properties of asphalt binder are presented as follow:
4.1.4. Linear amplitude sweep (LAS) The LAS test can be used to measure the fatigue life of asphalt binders. PAV aged binders are tested with an 8-mm-diamater plate and a 2 mm gap at 25 C. Both frequency sweep test and amplitude sweep test are conducted. The frequency sweep from 0.2 to 30 Hz can provide information regarding original material property. And during the amplitude sweep test, the loading amplitude is linearly increased from 0 to 30% at 10 Hz.
4.1.5. Surface free energy (SFE) The SFE test can be used to determine the moisture property of asphalt binders, based on Wilhelmy Plate method. Samples and molten binder samples are mixed together by dipping the micro glass slide (Dimension of 24/50 mm, No 1.5). SFE test is done with a loading rate of 0.04 mm/s at 25 C. Three different liquid (Distilled water, Glycerol and Formamide) are used to measure the contact angle. Maintain very low speed is very important during the whole test.
Some more common used tests for asphalt mixtures are simply introduced as follow:
4.1.6. Indirect tensile strength test (ITS) The indirect tensile strength test can be used to evaluate the resistance of moisture damage. The samples are conducted by the method of AASHTO T283-03. ITS test loading is done with a loading rate of 5.08 cm/min until the sample is fractured. Maximum load value is recorded at the time of fracture.
4.1.7. Moisture susceptibility test The moisture susceptibility test can be used to measure the effect of water on the tensile strength of asphalt mixture. The
specimens are placed between the steel loading strips using in the indirect tensile test. The load is applied to the specimen at 50 mm/min and the maximum compressive force is recorded until the specimen cracked. It can be cited to reference from AASHTO/ ASTM standards.
4.1.8. Marshall test (ASTM 1559) The Marshall test is an empirical test in which cylindrical compacted specimens, 100 mm in diameter by approximately 63.5 mm in height, are immersed into the water at 60 C for 30–40 min. Then, they are loaded to failure using the curved steel loading plates along a diameter at a constant compression rate of 51 mm/min.
4.1.9. Indirect tensile fatigue (ITF) test Indirect tensile test of the ITF test method can be used to determine the fatigue life of asphalt. The samples are 100 mm in diameter and 40 mm in thickness. Samples are made according to ASTM D1559 standard.
4.2. Advanced techniques
In civil engineering as well as pavement engineering, many effective macro-scale techniques are employed to evaluate the characterization of materials. However, there are still many problems using macro-scale techniques that have not been understood clearly and still unsolved yet.
In order to explore the characterizations of nano-scale structure behaviors of nano-composite asphalts and their fracture morphologies, various techniques such as scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), nano-CT scanning and Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) were conducted by researchers as presented in Table 11.
4.2.1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) Electron microscopy is a bombardment of electron to the sample and captures the reflected electrons or radiated electrons out of the sample. From the SEM images, the morphologies of original binder, nanomaterial, modified asphalt binder and modified asphalt mixture can be observed. Therefore, SEM test method is regarded as a powerful tool to understand the microstructure of composites and the failure mechanism of asphalt material.
In recent decade, more and more researchers have utilized SEM to observe the morphology of microstructure and the fracture surface of nano-modified asphalt. Khattak et al. [60] investigated the fracture surface of nanofiber modified binder as well as the molecular structure of neat binder, CNF, and modified binder. They observed that the CNF was completely coated with asphalt. And CNFs were pulled out with the asphalt under a tensile loading and formed the ‘‘cone-shape” structure.
Another study by Kim et al. [14] found that fracture healing occurred during the rest period of loading, based on SEM images. In conclusion, nanomaterials have a high adhesive force with asphalt which can produce a bridging effect. In addition, because
of the crack bridging between asphalt and nanoparticle, the generation and development of micro-cracks can be prevented. As a result, the fatigue life can be extended and the rutting resistance can be improved. SEM images for these nano modified asphalts on different scales are summarized as follows (Fig. 1):
From these pictures, it can be concluded that images with a scale of 1 lm can clearly describe the morphology of molecular structure and interactions compared with those images with a scale of 100 lm. However, these large scaled images still effectively describe the dispersion of nanoparticles.
4.2.2. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) AFM is a scanning probe microscopy technique with a very high resolution. In an AFM test, the surface of the sample is probed by laser-tracked cantilever with a sharp AFM tip and the attractive or repulsive force between the tip and the sample surface is measured.
In general, there are two main applications of AFM used in studying asphalt. At first, AFM technique is widely employed to examine the nano-scale and micro-scale forces for a complicated material. So AFM tests are used to examine the adhesion between the asphalt and the aggregate as well as the cohesive bond within an asphalt binder. For example, Hill et al. [89] used AFM to measure the surface roughness of nano device fabricated for the
micro-electronic technology. Another application of AFM is to examine nano- and microstructure of original and modified binders. The dispersion degree of nano-modified asphalt was evaluated by comparing the topographical and phase images both the modified and pristine asphalt binders.
Nazzal et al. [81] and his coworkers used AFM to examine whether the nano-particles were uniformly dispersed within the asphalt binder. To achieve this goal, they made the sample with a dimension of 60 60 lm and found the topographical images of ‘‘beelike structure” between the control asphalt and the nanomodified asphalt were similar and no additional structures in modified asphalt at 60 60 lm scale were observed. As a result, nanoparticles were considered uniformly dispersed into the asphalt. In addition, it was indicated that the addition of nano-clay showed better interaction between the nano-clay layers and more distinct ‘‘bee-like” structures as compared to the unmodified asphalt, based on AFM images. However, another research conducted by Zhang et al. [85] presented different results, which indicated the phase contrasts were inverted and decreased at 15 15 lm scale after added OMMT (Fig. 2). In addition, the boundary between the domain and matrix disappeared.
Furthermore, Li et al. [25] used this method to analyze the morphology characteristics of the binders after a thin film oven test and/or an ultraviolet aging. It can be found that the contrast
between the matrix and dispersed domains decreased. Also, the single-phase trend occurred during these aged procedures.
4.2.3. X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD technique has been used to investigate the morphological features and chemical reactions of asphalt binder based on XDR images obtained from diffractometer with Cu K radiation. It was believed that XDR is a powerful tool to analyze molecularlevel interactions of nano-clays and characterize the morphology of the final nano-modified asphalt binder system.
XRD spectra are used to declare the distance (d001) between two layers of nano-clays before and after mixed with the asphalt. Liu et al. [44] found that the d001 of Montmorillonite nano-clay (Mt) increased from 2.1 nm to 4.2 nm, implying that asphalt molecules merged into the Mt and the distance between the nano-clays increased. Meanwhile, Jahromi [28] demonstrated that the spectrum of asphalt moved the top of the layer with the increase of nano-clay content. The increased interlayer spacing indicated asphalts were able to inter implant into the clay at micro level. This maybe a result of polymer penetrated between the neighboring layers of the nano-clays.
In conclusion, the d001 values increased after mixed with asphalt which indicating the distance of two layers increased, due to the interaction at molecular level. The d001 values were summarized in Fig. 3.
4.2.4. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) is a technique, which can analyze samples qualitatively and quantitatively. Thus, it is widely used in industry such as medicine, chemistry, mining, oil, coal, customs, gemstone and forensic identification. According to the assignations of FTIR spectra main bands, researchers can observe the bonding characteristics of the tested materials. The main band assignments and positions are summarized in Table 12 [22,66,67,78,87,90]. Based on the band assignments and positions, molecular-level interactions and chemical bonding of asphalt binder can be analyzed. So FTIR was regarded as a powerful tool to investigate the chemical compositions of nano-modified asphalt.
Yao and his coworkers [66,67] analyzed the anti-aging impacts of the nano-modified binders based on the FTIR test images and results. In their study, the changes of function groups were observed during the process of oxidation and the carbonyl index as the aging index was used to evaluate the degree of aging. Based on previous literature, the carbonyl index would increase after an oxidation [91]. However, the content of carboxylic acids decreased after a procedure of PTFO [30], which illustrated that nanosilica had the potential to improve the aging resistance and delay the aging process of asphalt binder. Another study by Abdelrahman [22] evaluated the interactions between nano-clay and asphalt binder based on FTIR, showed that the temperature susceptibility of nano-modified asphalt was dramatically enhanced due to the strong molecular coactions between tetrahedron structure of Si@O and asphalt binder.
4.2.5. Nano-CT scanning The nanotom CT scanner can be used to observe the distribution image of nano particles in the asphalt system by radiation of an X-ray tube at 120 kV. Liu et al. used CT scanning equipment to investigate the distribution of nano-scale particles in the asphalt system. The sodium montmorillonite particles were found dispers-
ing in asphalt system like the conventional filler at micrometer scale [88].
5. Performance properties
5.1. 1Asphalt performance
5.1.1. Visco-elasticity It is well known that adding nano-particle as modification additive has the potential to enhance the complex shear modulus and reduce the phase angle. As a result, it would display a dramatic enhancement of visco-elasticity of asphalt binder.
Nano-clay is a popular choice for researchers to modify the asphalt due to its adequate source and low price. All researchers such as Khodaii [28], You [53], Yao [64] and Abdelrahman [22] indicated that after the addition of nano-clay, modified asphalt showed much higher elasticity and stiffness than base binder. You et al. [53] discovered that the complex shear modulus of 4% nano-clay modified binder was improved to 125% while the G⁄ value of 2% nano-clay can be increased about 66%. In addition, another type of nano-clay can improve the G⁄ by 196% at the content of 4% and if adding 2% of that nano-clay also can increase the G⁄ up to 184%. Furthermore, Yao and his coworker [64] concluded that the complex shear modulus of polymer modified nano-clay (PNM) showed a tide of slightly reduction while the addition of non-modified nano-clay (NMN) could noticeably raise the value of G⁄. Those results indicated that the type and content of nanoclay would have significant influences on nanocomposites system and impacts on the performances of visco-elasticity.
When copolymer modified asphalt binder was used, montmorillonite (MMT) and styrene–butadiene–styrene (SBS) copolymer modified asphalt displayed enhanced visco-elastic properties and resistance to rutting at a high temperature [10]. Another study also found the organophilic montmorillonite (OMMT)/SBS modified system exhibited higher G⁄ value and lower phase angle [59]. The variation results of G⁄ values were shown in Fig. 4.
5.1.2. High-temperature property The rutting factor is defined as G⁄/sind, which is an indicator of the rutting resistance of the asphalt binder in the Superpave asphalt binder specification. The higher the G⁄/sind, the stronger high temperatures resistance to rutting performance of the modified asphalt. The G⁄/sind of CNF-modified asphalt binder increased up to 47% compared with the original one and showed a better rutting resistance [33]. Another research also proposed the rutting factor could be enhanced by the introduced proper content of nanoclay or/and nanosilica [61]. Similarly, Yu et al. studied the influence of SBR/MMT copolymer modified binder on the rutting
resistance [7]. In their study, both montmorillonite (MMT) and organophilic-montmorillonite (OMMT) exhibited improvements in both complex shear modulus and phase angle of the modified asphalt. Owing to the formation of exfoliated structure, OMMT modified asphalt exhibited better rutting resistance performance compared with MMT modified one in accordance with Zhang and his coworkers [10]. Fig. 5 concluded the G⁄/sind of the modified binders from different researchers [33,35,92].
In addition, Yao et al. [64] used the indicator of dissipated energy to evaluate the resistance to rutting property of nano modified asphalt. The findings showed that the dissipated energy increased by an average of 50% when used 4% nonmodified nanoclay (NMN) modified asphalt binder. And that of 2% NMN modified asphalt binder raised by an average of 12%. As a result, NMN modified asphalt showed higher dissipated energy per loading cycle which implied the addition of NMN improve the resistance to rutting after the RTFO aging process. Therefore, the addition of the NMN was considered to enhance the rutting resistance of the asphalt pavement.5.1.3 Low-temperature property.
Fang et al. [37] concluded that low-temperature cracking resistance had been improved significantly by adding nanoparticles (Silicon dioxide, Titanium dioxide, Zinc oxide) into the base asphalt. In addition, from experiments conducted by Shahabadi et al. [63], the creep stiffness values of both bentonite clay (BT) and organically modified bentonite (OBT) modified binders showed remarkable reductions which indicated that the addition of nano materials could effectively resist the low temperature cracking.
Other BBR test results found the stiffness values of NMN and PMN modified binders were nearly same as those of neat binders [64]. More than that, Abdelrahman et al. [22] demonstrated that
ormances [22,53,63,64].
the addition of nano-clays would increase the stiffness, and decrease the m-value of neat asphalt. Above all, the lowtemperature performances of different nano-modified asphalts were distinct from each other. Fig. 6 concluded the stiffness values and m-values of the modified binders from different researchers [22,53,63,64].
In addition, other tests were used to evaluate the lowtemperature behaviors of nano-modified asphalts. For instance, You et al. [53] executed DDT tests to analyze the low service temperature performance of nana-clay modified asphalt. The findings indicated that adding nano-clays to modify original asphalt decreased its strain percent at failure, which may result in higher potential to cracking at low service temperatures. Another study by Li et al. [52] also confirmed the addition of nanomaterials substantially improved the ductility of asphalt binder.
5.1.3. Aging property Aging is one of the primary factors resulting in the deterioration of asphalt pavements. It occurs during the production and mixing processes as well as during a long-term service life. How to improve the resistance of oxidation and prolong the service duration of asphalt pavement is a big challenge for highway pavement engineers. In recent decades, many researchers proposed that nano-particles can effectively solve this aging problem. Different tests and indicators were utilized to assess this aging characteristics of nano modified asphalt binder [8,25,28,30,36,49,63,78,83]. The results were concluded in Table 13.
Although researchers conducted different tests and used different indicators when analyzed the anti-aging performance of nano-modified asphalt, similar results could be concluded that nanomaterials do have the potentials to improve the resistance of aging. With respect to nano-clays modification, it was proven that pristine asphalt binder modified by nano-clays showed better resistance to aging when sufficient dispersion was achieved [63]. Walters et al. proposed that the use of both 6% Cloisite-11 and 3% Cloisite-11 combined with 3% bio-char could enhance the characteristics of aging resistance of neat asphalt [58]. Yao and his coworkers also investigated three types of nano-clays (nanomer 1.44P, non-modified Nano-clay and polymer-modified Nano-clay) and indicated that addition of nano-clay weakened and postponed the oxidation process and showed great potential to prolong the service life of the modified asphalt pavement [67].
In addition, Yao et al. demonstrated that nano-SiO2, nano-clays and nanofibers had the positive influences on resisting the aging of asphalt binder [30,67]. Zhou et al. [14] employed layered double hydroxides (LDHs) in their study and illustrated that the degradation of asphalt binder when exposed to water and oxygen was
dominant reaction and LDHs modified asphalts showed better high-temperature stability during the thermal aging process without oxygen compared to base binder. Santagata et al. [36] utilized Aging Index to evaluate the susceptibility to oxidative aging by adding CNTs to the modified asphalt and found that the susceptibility to aging resistance was improved.
Similarly, Zhang (2012) [86], Li (2010) [25], and Yu (2009) [8] investigated the rheological properties of Montmorillonite (MMT)/SBS modified binder after a ultraviolet (UV) aging procedure. Compared with pristine binder, it was found that the values of both Viscosity Aging Index (VAI) and Softening Point Increment (SPI) decreased after the introduction of OMMT. The findings confirmed that the aging resistance to Ultraviolet light was enhanced by additional OMMT/SBS additive. The similar conclusion was convinced by Li et al. [83]. Their study found that SMN-ZnO copolymer modified asphalt could improve the anti-aging performance. In addition, Wang et al. [49] utilized nano-scale titanium oxide to change the oxidation resistance property of asphalt binder. In their study, British Pendulum Number (BPN) and macro-texture depth (MTD) were used to evaluate the UV and oxidative aging properties of asphalt binders. Both BPN and MTD values increased, indicating the anti-aging property was enhanced by the addition of nanoTiO2.
5.1.4. Adhesion Yu et al. [51] indicated that nano-clay could provide an intensive interaction between the asphalt and additive due to the large active surface area (up to 700–800 m2/g) and very high aspect ratio. Nazzal and his coworkers also revealed that nano-clay
modifiers improved the adhesive forces of the asphalt but slightly decreased the cohesive force [81]. In addition, nano-SiO2 powder modified binders tended to show the improved adhesive bonding between nanoparticles and binders and generally presented better viscosity properties than base binders [32].
Moreover, Nazzal et al. and his coworkers utilized AFM technique to evaluate the adhesive between asphalt and aggregate by using different tips (silicon nitride tip and ACOOH tip). The results were showed Fig. 7 [81].
Based on the AFM results, the adhesive forces between the asphalt and silicon nitride tip showed a significantly enhancement. The modified binders with additional 4% nano-clays showed larger adhesive forces than nano-composites containing 2% nano-clays. However, results were different when used -COOH tip because the value of adhesive force decreased with the addition of nanoclay owing to the hydrophilia of ACOOH.
5.1.5. Fatigue It has been indicated that the addition of organomontmorillonites (OMMT) can be beneficial in improving fatigue resistance of modified asphalt by analyzing its dissipated energy [44]. This may be the result of the adequate interfacial interaction between the asphalt and nano-clay particle at molecular level. In addition, Khattak et al. conducted the repeated shear stress test under sinusoidal loading to evaluate the fatigue behavior of asphalt pavement [60]. It was found that the number of load cycles reaching 50% G⁄ increased from 2450 to 6530 when modified with 2.5% CNF by wet method. And regardless of mixing process, nano content and binder type, the fatigue lives of CNF modified binders were prolonged up to 2–3 times.
In addition, some researchers used the LAS test to evaluate the fatigue behavior of asphalt binder. It was found that the number of load cycle to failure increased with an increase in nanoclay content and the fatigue performance of nanoclay-modified binder was improved compared with the original binder [70]. Similarly, Kavussi and his co-workers also found the fatigue life of nanoclay-modified binder and nano hydrated lime were improved up to 40% and 49%, relatively [71].
5.2. Asphalt mixture performance
5.2.1. High-temperature stability It has been confirmed that nano-modified asphalt mixtures have better potential to resist permanent deformation and exhibit an enhancement of high-temperature performance [23,56]. Shafabakhsh [47] found that adding nanosilica (nano-SiO2) and nano titanium (nano-TiO2) to the modified asphalt mixtures would significantly increase the Marshal stability and decrease the final strain of unmodified asphalt. A 3D model was established to analyze the creep behavior of asphalt binder at different temperatures and stresses based on Matlab software. It was concluded that the creep behavior was dramatically enhanced even at high levels of stress and temperature, which was also convinced by Yusoff et al. [29].
Meanwhile, Tanzadeh et al. evaluated the effect of nano-TiO2 on rutting performance of asphalt pavements [93]. The results illustrated that using nano-TiO2 in asphalt binder samples reduces the rutting depth in comparison with the ordinary mixtures. Cheng and his coworkers [26] found that mixtures processed by nano-size hydrated lime significantly enhanced the indirect tensile strength (ITS), toughness and flow number. The indicators used to evaluate the high-temperature behavior were summarized in Table 14 as followed:
5.2.2. Low-temperature crack resistance A study by Yao [30] found the introduction of nanosilica only had very limited influence on the m-value and stiffness of base binder. The m-values of base binder and 4% nano-silica modified binder only varied from 0.317 to 0.306 and the low-temperature grade of the nano-silica modified binder remained the same as the base asphalt. So it was believed the nano-silica modifier had no ability to improve the low-temperature performance.
5.2.3. Fatigue performance Carbon nanofiber is well known as a new material with high modulus and tensile strength, large aspect ratio and good network which would be beneficiary to hindrance the cracking development and consequently prolong the fatigue life of HMA. Khattak et al. 2012 [68] conducted the fatigue test under the indirect tensile test and found that the number of load cycles increased from 71,233 to 140,956 which indicated the fatigue life of CNF modified HMA exhibited a dramatic improvement of 98% compared with the base one.
In addition, similar conclusion was drawn by Arabani and his coworkers [94], indicating that the addition of nano-SiO2 exhibited an increment of the number of cycle. However, the rising trend of fatigue life was stop by adding more than 6% nano-SiO2 particles. Shafabakhsh et al. [47] [55] illustrated that adding a relatively high percentage (3% by weight of the asphalt binder) of Nano-TiO2 or/ and Nano-SiO2 can effectively prolong the service life of asphalt pavement.
5.2.4. Moisture damage Moisture damage occurs when the adhesion and/or cohesion of asphalt pavement is lost. Even though the moisture susceptibility had been studied for over 80 years, but still remained some unsolved problems. The loss of adhesion and cohesion were considered as the result of the water effect. The broken bonds between asphalt and aggregate typically occur at a nano-scale. So nanoscale modifiers were regarded as a powerful material to improve the moisture resistance performance of asphalt mixtures.
Tensile strength ratio (TSR) method was the most common way to investigate the moisture resistance of asphalt mixture. Based on this method, nanosilica (nano-SiO2) had the potential to enhance the anti-stripping property and decrease the susceptibility to moisture damage of asphalt mixture [29,67]. So nano-SiO2 modifier was a good choice to reduce the possibility of moisture damage. Mean-
while, Shi and his coworkers [76] declared that the use of a relatively high percentage of poly siloxane-modified montmorillonite and/or carbon microfiber (both at less than 2%) can enhance the anti-moisture ability of asphalt mixture. The addition of nano-clay and carbon fiber also had the ability to decrease the potential moisture damage of asphalt binder in most cases [31]. In addition, Cheng et al. [26] introduced the nano-sized hydrated lime to asphalt mixture and found a better anti-stripping performance. Another study by Ghasemi et al. [32] demonstrated that mixtures modified with 5% SBS and 2% nano-SiO2 powder had the remarkable improvement in TSR values. The TSR results of different nano-particles modified asphalt mixtures were concluded in Fig. 8 [29,31,32,56,74].
Specially, Hamedi and his co-workers [72,74], Hossain et al. [73] and Ashish et al. [69] utilized surface free energy (SFE) method to analyze the moisture damage resistivity of asphalt. Hamedi et al. [72] demonstrated that the addition of nano-ZnO increased the total Surface Free Energy (SFE). Similarly, improvement in the total SFE was observed with the addition of nano-clay in another two papers [69,73]. And basalt is the most compatible aggregate with nano-clay modified asphalt. The Total SFE results of different nano-particles modified asphalt mixtures were concluded in Fig. 9 [69,72,73].
Overall, the results from both TSR method and SFE method proposed that the moisture resistance of nano modified binders was significantly improved compared with that of base binders.
5.2.5. Aging performances Yusoff et al. [29] used the aging index to evaluate the degree of oxidation. The value of aging index was obtained from the ratio of
the aged resilient modulus to unaged one. In their study, 4% nanosilica modified with the binder after a PAV procedure exhibited the highest aging index. Yao et al. [30] conducted the FTIR test and analyzed the ratio changes of bands of nano-SiO2 modified asphalt, indicating nano-SiO2 was an effective material to improve the aging resistance of asphalt mixtures.
6. Cost consideration
Hossain and his coworkers declared that the cost of PG 70-28 binder and PG 76-28 were about $798 and $1064 per metric ton, respectively. The required amount of nanoclays to manufacture nano-modified PG 70-28 and PG 76-28 binders was 2% and 4%, respectively. Based on market data, the cost of nanoclays was about $4.96/kg, the cost of modified PG 70-28 and PG 76-28 binders was $622 and $712, respectively. As a result, the cost to manufacture nanoclay modified PG 70-28 and PG 76-28 binders was reduced 22% and 33%, respectively compared with polymer modified binders [73], Similarly, the cost of development of organmodified montmorillonite binders showed a significant decreased for the low cost and abundance in nature of nanoclays. Along with the consideration of cost, energy consumption and environment influence also needed to be taken into consideration during the construction period [70].Therefore, it is necessary to carry out economic, ecological and environmental evaluations of nano-modified asphalt before a large-scale application in practical engineering.
7. Summarizes
1. Many factors had effects on the properties of nano-modified asphalt binder, including binder type, particle type, particle content, particle size, production process and so on. At present, research study mainly focused on analyzing nanoparticle type, production process, and nano-particle content of modified binders. Other factors such as binder type and particle size needed to be taken into consideration. 2. Nanomaterials could improve the adhesive force of the asphalt and produced ‘‘bridging” effect between the asphalt and nanoparticle, preventing from the generation and development of micro-cracks. As a result, the fatigue life could be prolonged and the permanent deformation could be decreased. 3. An effective dispersion of the nano-material into the asphalt during the production process was still a big challenge. It was believed that the degree of dispersion was governed by the factors such as mixing temperature, duration and speed. In addition, the natures of nano-material and original binder played the key roles in determining optimum production process parameters. Future research study could be conducted to analyze the influence of mixing parameters on guaranteeing the uniform nano material modified binder. 4. How to effectively evaluate if the dispersion of the nanomaterial was uniform was still unsolved yet. Quantitative assessment system should be proposed to evaluate the degree of nano-particle dispersion. 5. Nano-particle as modified additive had the potential to enhance the complex shear modulus, reduced the phase angle and finally improved rheological performance of base binder. 6. The addition of nano-clay, carbon fiber or tube and spherical particle (nano-ZnO, nano-SiO2, nano-TiO2, and nano-CaCO3) significantly improved the low-temperature cracking resistance as well as the high temperature performance. So it was believe that nano-scale modifier had the potential to enhance the temperature stability.
7. Nano particles such as nano-ZnO, nano-SiO2, and nano-clay had the potential to delay the oxidation process and eventually improved the aging resistance. Specially, nano- TiO2 could be used to improve the property of against UV aging of asphalt binder. 8. All of nano-SiO2, nano-CaCO3, nano-ZnO and nano-clay had potential to improve the moisture resistance of asphalt mixture. Among them, nano-SiO2 exhibited the best modification characteristics in terms of the anti-moisture performance. 9. Studies based on the nano modified mixtures were obvious less than those based on nano modified binders, thus further studies should concentrate on behaviors of nano modified mixtures, especially low-temperature property. 10. Economic, ecological and environmental evaluations of nano-modified asphalt also need to be considered before a large-scale application in practical engineering.

metadata.abstractText: Due to its nature of large surface area and small size, nano-material shows specific characteristics compared to the common material and exhibits some novel properties and incredible features which make it possible to be applied in the field of asphalt pavement as an additive. This review focuses on introducing the main nano materials and related techniques used for nano-modified asphalts and major performance characteristics at various states. Some conventional test results including viscosity, dynamic modulus, stiffness, rut depth, indirect tensile strength and so on were employed to characterize the rheological and engineering performances of nano-modified asphalts and some innovative technologies such as atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy were effectively utilized to explore their micro structures and molecular components. It can be found that the addition of nanomaterials could dramatically enhance the properties of an asphalt material such as visco-elasticity, high temperature properties, and the resistances to aging, fatigue and moisture. In addition, nano-particle type, content and production process were mainly studied and other factors such as binder type and particle size also need to be considered to explore the modification mechanism and effect. The properties of both nano-material and original binder played the key roles in determining optimal production process parameters. In addition, the degree of dispersion was governed by some factors such as the mixing temperature, duration and speed. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
